author: quezacoa
content:
Question about (dank)sharding: I understand that L1 transactions will probably never be "cheap" and one should focus on L2 solutions to transfer low values without having to pay massive fees.

What about small amounts of ETH close to or below the current tx-fee height on single addresses? Can those ever be claimed?

In the original sharding concept with 64 shards gas prices would have dropped by 64x once enabled... If the demand did not 64x until then, one would have had the chance to transfer small balances right after the rollout, right? But this concept is no more the plan AFAIK.

Will the danksharding concept have a similar impact on L1 fees? I didn't completely get it, I guess.

Or is there any other way to claim those small balances? AFAIK one has to do at least one L1 transaction to an exchange or against a L2 smart contract to liquefy those small balances.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
There have been a few mentions of the idea, for instance: https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/some-medium-term-dust-cleanup-ideas/6287

There are other models: I believe Polkadot deletes balances with less than 1 DOT.

author: chris2_2_2
content:
64x capacity leads to much greater than 64x reduction.

For instance if road capacity increases 5x more people will drive but there wonâ€™t be 5x more people driving. As time passes obviously demand will increase though.

author: quezacoa
content:
Yeah sure, demand is the main variable. 

Is 64 shards still the long term plan or does danksharding make those obsolete?

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: I believe the previous plan (in the execution-shard days) was for 1024 shards long-term, and an initial deployment of 64 shards.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: I'm unsure as to whether technical complexity, validator count or user count (non-consensus full nodes) were the bottleneck / limiting factor on initial shard count.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
In the previous sharding model, one still wants enough validators per shard-committee I believe, otherwise the likelihood / feasibility of 'bad shard attacks' becomes intolerable. 

Similarly we'd like many users to be monitoring the chain (this point is emphasised in Celestia's claim that through data availability sampling, as user count increases so too will tolerable blocksizes), so it may be wiser to have fewer shards than the maximum the system is capable of.

author: chris2_2_2
content: I suspect the # of shards will be raised very slowly, too many unknown security and attack vectors.

author: quezacoa
content: But there will still be shards to increase L1 capabilities? Within or following danksharding?
